title: Living with Covid vs zero Covid
text:
Good evening,

We report today from both ends of the debate about pandemic restrictions, as the UK forges ahead with its “living with Covid” policy while China tightens its “zero Covid” rules, with both stances encountering heavy resistance.

NHS leaders today demanded ministers disclose the scientific basis for the premature relaxation of rules in England, which could see the end of free lateral flow tests as well as the requirement to self-isolate after a positive Covid-19 test. They also argue that a subsequent uptick in infections could wreck plans to reduce health service waiting lists, which have lengthened considerably during the pandemic.

Meanwhile, the return to the office has picked up, with workplace occupancy in the UK hitting 27 per cent this week — the highest since the pandemic began. This is however still far short of pre-crisis levels, with the full effect of hybrid working yet to be seen. Other measures of activity such as the number of flights arriving in and leaving the UK are also on the rise.

Contrast all this with the picture in Hong Kong, where a return to some kind of normality seems a very long way off, even prompting an announcement today that the territory's leadership elections would be postponed from March until May.

Even as infections surge — highlighted by today's closure of part of HSBC's main office after several staff were found to be infected — the city's local business community has been chafing against China's strict pandemic restrictions. These include isolating all positive cases in hospitals and quarantine centres, even if people have only mild symptoms or are asymptomatic.

Beijing fears the Hong Kong outbreak — China's worst in more than two years — could threaten the mainland, but banks such as Standard Chartered say the measures risk the territory losing its prized status as a financial hub.

The FT revealed yesterday that Prudential's new chief might have to start the job from outside the city because of the “friction” created by the rules, while international companies from Pernod Ricard to Mandarin Oriental are already looking at temporarily relocating staff elsewhere.

However, complaints are likely to fall on deaf ears. According to one veteran member of Hong Kong's pro-Beijing camp, President Xi Jinping would not hesitate to take more drastic measures to eradicate the outbreak and restore the territory to near-zero Covid levels. “Do not,” he said, “underestimate the Communist party's determination.”

Latest news

  • Eurozone consumer confidence has fallen to an 11-month low

  • Oxford university researchers said long Covid was emerging as a major long-term issue for global healthcare systems (Reuters)

  • Deere raised its profit forecast as supply chain problems and increased production costs were offset by strong demand and higher prices for its agricultural machinery

For up-to-the-minute news updates, visit our live blog

Need to know: the economy

Former UK prime minister Gordon Brown said sharing the global Covid burden was one of the most cost-effective investments G20 countries could make this year. “The world will be a more dangerous place, and global recovery impeded, if an item that has been at the top of finance ministers' agendas for the past two years — the pandemic and the financing of the global health response — is downgraded . . . out of a misguided complacency that we are now in the Covid endgame,” he writes.

Latest for the UK and Europe

UK retail sales rebounded a better than expected 1.9 per cent in January after shrinking the previous month. A tripling of profits at warehouse owner Segro highlights how the online shopping boom has split the fortunes of commercial landlords during the pandemic. In contrast to Segro, those reliant on income from bricks and mortar stores have struggled to recoup rents.

Economic disparities between UK regions have widened during the pandemic, giving new impetus to the government's “levelling up” proposals.

The European Central Bank's chief economist has shifted his position on inflation by saying it looks unlikely to drop below the ECB's 2 per cent target in the next two years, notes Frankfurt bureau chief Martin Arnold. Inflation is the key factor in determining how quickly the ECB should start dismantling its stimulus programme.

In energy news, the head of Italian oil major Eni said the gas market would remain tight for at least four years as it reported its highest annual profits since 2021, while France said it would pump €2bn into state-controlled EDF to help the group with production problems. The company will also take on some of the costs of government measures to cap household and business electricity bills.

Global latest

The FT Editorial Board looks at the hard choices facing central banks as they start tightening policy and raising interest rates. US economics editor Colby Smith analyses chair Jay Powell's chances of achieving consensus at a divided Federal Reserve.

Japan has had zero inflation and interest rates for decades and consequently low expectations for wage rises. But with prices rising, as our Big Read explains, this year's bargaining round could be different.

Need to know: business

NatWest, the UK state-owned bank, reported a strong bounceback in 2021, thanks to fewer bad loans and a revival in the mortgage market. Net profits hit £2.95bn compared with a £753mn loss in 2020. Bumper bonuses for bankers are unlikely to go down well with the public, cautions UK business writer Cat Rutter Pooley. But if you're one of the lucky recipients, consumer editor Claer Barrett has some tips on how to spend it.

Renault reported its first profit in two years of €967mn, compared with an €8bn loss in 2020 after slashing costs. The French carmaker warned however that it expected to make 300,000 fewer vehicles this year because of the global chip shortage. It also warned of supply chain problems for its Russian plants if the situation in Ukraine escalates.

There were more encouraging signs for the future of air travel as aircraft maker Airbus bounced back with record profits of €4.2bn and announced its first dividend since the onset of the pandemic. Air France-KLM announced plans to repay state aid and raise fresh capital after a lower than expected loss for 2021 and fourth-quarter operating income above pre-pandemic levels. Unhedged writer Robert Armstrong parses Wall Street thinking on the prospects for airline stocks.

Walmart announced a $10bn share buyback alongside an upbeat outlook for this financial year after better than expected sales of $152.9bn for the three months ending in January. The US retail giant, which has successfully targeted cost-conscious Americans, said the average price gap with its competition “continues to widen versus pre-pandemic levels”.

Gulp! The £10 pint (in London at least) could be here sooner than expected. The beer industry warned that rising costs from raw materials, staff and utilities, combined with the end of pandemic tax relief, could soon hit drinkers' pockets.

So much for being “Covid-proof”. Read our tale of connected fitness company Peloton's wild ride from investors' darling to its crash back to earth.

Science round up

Pandemic management: UK scientists joined health leaders in warning against the scrapping of free Covid tests in the government's new “living with Covid” strategy to be published next week.

The UK is also preparing to revamp its biosecurity strategy following a highly critical parliamentary report that “exposed profound shortcomings” in its approach to the pandemic.

UK scientists have launched a study to assess the effect of Covid variants on newborns and their mothers to try and address low vaccination take-up among pregnant women.

Peak flu season has been restrained by pandemic restrictions, raising the possibility of a spring or summer surge. Up to 650,000 people die globally each year from respiratory diseases linked to seasonal flu, according to the World Health Organization.

Vaccines: Moderna, the US mRNA vaccine pioneer, is in talks with the UK government about investing in research and manufacturing, a move that could offer a significant boost to the country's post-Brexit science strategy.

England this week joined Scotland and Wales in announcing plans for vaccines to be offered to children aged five to 11.

Treatments: Merck's antiviral pill molnupiravir faces problems getting approval from EU regulators who have cited “problematic” data. US counterparts have approved the bill but restricted its use, while France cancelled its order over concerns of efficacy.

Health authorities in Brazil are fighting against an upsurge in quack Covid remedies, often promoted by the Bolsonaro administration. More than 600,000 Brazilians have died from Covid-19, the second-highest number in the world after the US.

On a related note, columnist John Gapper discusses the “nocebo effect”, where the fear of side effects from vaccines and other medicines turns into a self-fulfilling prophecy of harm.
